topics.title: The Preamble
topics.description: Understanding the soul of the Indian Constitution

content.title: What is the Preamble?
content.body:
The **Preamble** is the introductory statement of the Indian Constitution. It was adopted on **26th November 1949** and came into effect on **26th January 1950**.

## Key Points:
- Based on the **'Objectives Resolution'** by Jawaharlal Nehru (13 Dec 1946)
- Declares India as **Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic**
- Outlines the objectives: Justice, Liberty, Equality, Fraternity

### Source of Authority
The Constitution derives its authority from **'We, the People of India'**.
content.mnemonic: PRAJYA - Preamble Reveals All Justice, Liberty, Equality, Fraternity Yearnings

quiz.prompt: The Preamble of the Indian Constitution is based on which resolution?
quiz.reason: The Preamble is based on the 'Objectives Resolution' drafted and moved by Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946.
The Preamble was adopted on 26th November 1949, but came into effect on 26th January 1950.

subTopics.title: Pillars of the Preamble
subTopics.description: The 5 key components that define India

content.title: Sovereign
content.body:
**Sovereign** means India is internally and externally independent.

- Not dependent on any external power
- Free to conduct its own affairs
- Added in the original Preamble (1949)

content.title: Socialist
content.body:
**Socialist** was added by the **42nd Amendment (1976)**.

- Promotes social and economic equality
- Mixed economy (public + private sector)
- Not strict socialism like USSR

content.title: Secular
content.body:
**Secular** was added by the **42nd Amendment (1976)**.

- State has no official religion
- Equal respect for all religions
- Freedom of religion (Article 25-28)

quiz.prompt: Which word declares that the Head of State is elected?
quiz.reason: 'Republic' means the head of state (the President) is elected, not a hereditary monarch.

topics.title: Schedules of Constitution
topics.description: The 12 schedules that organize constitutional provisions

content.title: What are Schedules?
content.body:
**Schedules** are lists in the Constitution that categorize bureaucratic activity and government policy.

## Originally 8 Schedules, Now 12:
1. **1st Schedule** - States and Union Territories
2. **2nd Schedule** - Salaries of officials
3. **3rd Schedule** - Oaths and Affirmations
4. **4th Schedule** - Rajya Sabha seat allocation
5. **5th Schedule** - Scheduled Areas and Tribes
6. **6th Schedule** - Tribal Areas (NE)
7. **7th Schedule** - Division of Powers (3 Lists)
8. **8th Schedule** - Recognized Languages
9. **9th Schedule** - Land reforms (added 1951)
10. **10th Schedule** - Anti-Defection Law (added 1985)
11. **11th Schedule** - Panchayats (added 1992)
12. **12th Schedule** - Municipalities (added 1992)
content.mnemonic: SSOA RSTT LLAM - Schedules Starting from One

quiz.prompt: Which schedule deals with the division of powers between Union and States?
quiz.reason: The 7th Schedule contains three lists: Union List, State List, and Concurrent List.
